facts.text: Appeal under Article 132 of the Constitution against Bombay High Court judgment dated 1st September 1950 in Criminal Application No. 807 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution against a judgment and order of the Bombay High Court dated 1st Sep- tember, 1950, in Criminal Application No. 807 of 1950.

facts.text: Respondent detained in custody under detention order made under Preventive Detention Act IV of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: ordering the release of the respondent who was detained in custody under a detention order made under the Preventive Detention Act  IV of 1950 . The re- spondent was first arrested on the 18th of December, 1948,

facts.text: Respondent released on 11th November 1949.

facts.text: Respondent arrested again on 21st April 1950 under Preventive Detention Act 1950.

anchor.surface_text: He was arrested again on the 21st of April, 1950, under the Preven- tive Detention Act, 1950, and on the 29th of April, 1950, grounds for his detention were supplied to him.

facts.text: Grounds for detention supplied to respondent on 29th April 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and on the 29th of April, 1950, grounds for his detention were supplied to him. They were in the following terms That you are engaged and are likely to be engaged in promoting acts

facts.text: Grounds stated: you are engaged and are likely to be engaged in promoting acts of sabotage on railway and railway property in Greater Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: They were in the following terms That you are engaged and are likely to be engaged in promoting acts of sabotage on railway and railway property in Greater Bombay. The respondent filed a habeas companynpus petition

facts.text: Respondent filed habeas corpus petition on 31st July 1950.

facts.text: In petition paragraphs 6 and 7: after release left Bombay stayed in Ratlam and Delhi, returned 20th April 1950 to Bombay and immediately arrested.

anchor.surface_text: On his release the applicant left Bombay and stayed out of Bombay, that is, in Ratlam and in Delhi. On 20th April, 1950, he returned to Bombay and was immediately arrested as stated above.

facts.text: Petition presented to court on 9th August 1950, court directed issue of notice to Commissioner of Police.

anchor.surface_text: When this petition was presented to the Court on the 9th of August, 1950, it directed the issue of a numberice to the Commissioner of Police.

facts.text: On 26th August 1950 Commissioner of Police sent communication with further particulars under section 7.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the disposal of the Rule, on the 26th August, 1950, the Commissioner of Police sent a companymunication to the respond- ent as follows In pursuance of section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950

facts.text: Further particulars: activities in grounds carried on in Greater Bombay between January 1950 and date of detention, likely to continue.

anchor.surface_text: That the activities mentioned in the grounds furnished to you were being carried on by you in Greater Bombay be- tween January 1950 and the date of your detention and In all probability you will companytinue to do so.

facts.text: On 30th August 1950 Commissioner of Police filed affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: On the 30th of August, 1950, the Commissioner of Police filed an affidavit against the petition of the respondent in which it was stated that the objectionable activities

facts.text: Affidavit stated objectionable activities between January 1950 and date of detention.

anchor.surface_text: in which it was stated that the objectionable activities were carried on by the applicant between the months of January, 1950, and the date of detention.

facts.text: In January 1950 move for total strike on railways in March 1950, respondent taking prominent part.

anchor.surface_text: It further stated that in or about the month of January, 1950, there was a move for a total strike on the railways in India in the month of March, 1950, and the applicant was taking prominent part

facts.text: Respondent and associates advocating sabotage on railways in Greater Bombay to make strike successful.

anchor.surface_text: to see that the strike was brought about and was successful. As a means to make the strike successful and bring about total cessation of work on all railways, the applicant and his associates were advocating sabotage

facts.text: Reliable materials from experienced police officers of respondent engaged in such activities.

anchor.surface_text: He further stated that reliable materials were put before him of the respondent being en- gaged in such activities by experienced police officers.

facts.text: Railway strike in March did not materialise but idea continued, respondent actively engaged for near future strike.

anchor.surface_text: He added that although the railways strike in the month of March did number materialise, the idea of bringing about such strike as soon as companyvenient companytinued to be entertained

facts.text: Disclosure of further facts against public interest.

anchor.surface_text: He then stated that the disclosure of further facts relating to the activities of the detenue was against public interest.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Anew and important question arises for our consideration and that is whether it is permissible to the detaining authority to justify the detention by amplify- ing and improving the grounds originally furnished The only grounds which we have to consider and which were furnished in the purported compliance of article 22 (5 ) were the grounds furnished to the detenue on the 29th of April, 1950

issues.text: the question of vagueness of grounds for the order of detention and the question whether supplementary grounds could be furnished after the grounds were first given to the detenue

anchor.surface_text: As the question of vagueness of grounds for the order of detention and the question whether supplementary grounds could be furnished after the grounds were first given to the detenue have arisen in various High Courts, we think it right that the general principles should be properly appreciated.

issues.text: Is it within the competence of the court to examine the grounds communicated to a person detained under the Act, with a view to see if they are sufficient in its opinion to enable him to make a representation to the detaining authority against the order, and if they are not, to direct his release?

anchor.surface_text: Put shortly, the question that falls to be decided is Is it within the competence of the court to examine the grounds communicated to a person detained under the Act, with a view to see if they are sufficient in its opinion to enable him to make a representation to the detaining authority against the order, and if they are not, to direct his release ?

issues.text: raises a very important question as to the sufficiency of the grounds of an order of detention under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: DAS J.--This appeal from a decision of the Bombay High Court raises a very important question as to the sufficiency of the grounds of an order of detention under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950. The question depends, for its answer, on a correct interpretation of clauses (5 ) and ( 6 ) of article 22 of our Constitution

arguments.claim: Article 22(5) permits communication of grounds as soon as may be, and earliest opportunity for representation; grounds are conclusions, particulars can follow if not new grounds

anchor.surface_text: Article 22 prescribes the minimum procedure that must be included in any law permitting preventive detention... When any person is detained in pursuance of an order made under any law providing for preventive detention, the authority making the order shall, as soon as may be, companymunicate to such person the ground on which the order has been made and shall afford him the earliest opportunity of making a representation against the order.

arguments.claim: Satisfaction under s3 PD Act is subjective, based on grounds rationally connected to objects; court cannot substitute objective test absent mala fides

anchor.surface_text: Section a of the Preventive Detention Act there- fore requires that the Central Government or the State Government must be satisfied... The satisfaction of the Government however must be based on some grounds... If, therefore, the grounds on which it is stated that the Central Government or the State Gov- ernment was satisfied are such as a rational human being can companysider companynected in some manner with the objects which were to be prevented from being attained, the question of satisfaction except on the ground of mala fides cannot be challenged in a companyrt.

arguments.claim: Later communication permissible if provides facts supporting original grounds, not new conclusions; no addition to grounds after first communication

anchor.surface_text: That is the general structure of article 22, clauses (5 ) and ( 6 ), of the Constitution. The question arising for discussion is what should be stated in the grounds... No part of such grounds can be held back number can any more grounds be added thereto... No interpolation into s3 requiring objective test via Art22(5); subjective satisfaction upheld per Gopalan

holdings.text: It is permissible for the detaining authority to furnish further particulars or facts supporting the original grounds of detention after the initial communication, provided such particulars do not constitute new grounds or conclusions and are supplied within a reasonable time consistent with affording the earliest opportunity for representation.

anchor.surface_text: If the sec- ond companymunication companytains numberfurther companyclusion of fact from facts, but only furnishes all or some of the facts on which the first mentioned companyclusion was rounded it is obvious that numberfresh ground for which the order of detention was made is being furnished to the detained person by the second companymunication which follows some time after the first companymunication. As regards the companytents of that companymunication therefore he test appears to be whether what is companyveyed in the second companymunication is a statement of facts or vents, which facts or events were already taken into companysideration in arriving at the companyclusion included in the ground already supplied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation of Art 22(5): grounds are conclusions supplied as soon as may be; particulars can follow to enable representation without adding new grounds; time factors distinct.

holdings.text: The satisfaction of the detaining authority under section 3 of the Preventive Detention Act is subjective and cannot be challenged in court unless grounds lack rational connection to statutory objects or mala fides is shown.

anchor.surface_text: Section a of the Preventive Detention Act there- fore requires that the Central Government or the State Government must be satisfied with respect to any person that with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to  1  the defence of India,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory wording requires government satisfaction; court cannot substitute objective test; follows precedent that grounds need only rational nexus, not legal proof.

holdings.text: Vague or indefinite grounds do not invalidate detention if they have rational connection to prejudicial acts; court can review vagueness only insofar as it prevents effective representation, distinct from review of satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: Although the ground may be good there may be a certain indefiniteness in its statement... the question whether the vagueness or indefinite nature of the statements furnished to the detained person is such as to give him the earliest opportunity to make a representation to the author- ity is a matter within the jurisdiction of the companyrts inquiry

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes test for validity (rational connection for subjective satisfaction) from test for representation (sufficiency of info); balances Art 22(5) rights.

holdings.text: It is not within the competence of the court to examine the sufficiency of grounds communicated to the detainee solely to determine if they enable an effective representation, as that is for the detaining authority's discretion under Art 22(6).

anchor.surface_text: Put shortly, the question that falls to be decided is Is it within the competence of the companyrt to examine the grounds communicated to a person detained under the Act, with a view to see if they are sufficient in its opinion to enable him to make a representation to the detaining authority against the order, and if they are number, to direct his release ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Gopalan; Art 22(6) privilege excludes judicial review of sufficiency; subjective scheme prevents objective test via representation right.

holdings.text: No addition to grounds after initial communication is allowed, as grounds must exist at time of order and be supplied as soon as may be; only supporting facts/particulars permitted.

anchor.surface_text: That is the general structure of article 22, clauses (5 ) and ( 6 ), of the Constitution. The question arising for discussion is what should be stated in the grounds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grounds are pre-existing conclusions from facts; cannot add post-order; Art 22(5) mandates completeness of grounds initially.

holdings.text: The original grounds supplied on 29th April 1950 were not vague and had rational connection; later particulars on 26th August supported them without new grounds; respondent's absence claim rejected; detention valid.

anchor.surface_text: We think that on the facts of the present case therefore the respondents petition should have been dismissed. We therefore allow the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies principles to facts: affidavit evidence shows activities in Bombay Jan-Apr 1950; counters petition claims; High Court erred in rejecting later communication outright.

holdings.text: Court cannot direct release merely because grounds are insufficient in its opinion to enable representation; review limited to mala fides, irrelevance, or non-compliance with procedure.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 22(5) does not import objective test; follows Gopalan upholding s.3; interpolation rejected; privilege under Art 22(6) confirms no judicial sufficiency review.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in holding that later particulars cannot rectify initial grounds; on facts, considering both, no violation of Art 22(5).

anchor.surface_text: We have indicated the circumstances and companyditions under which the later companymunication may or may number be companysidered as falling within the purview of article 22  5  of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this view is erroneous. We think that on the facts of the present case therefore the respondents petition should have been dismissed. We therefore allow the appeal. PATANJALI SASTRI. J.--While I concur in the order pro- posed by my Lord that this appeal should be allowed, I regret I find myself unable to agree with him on the true meaning and effect of article 22, clause  5 , which is reproduced in section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950,  hereinafter referred to as the Act . Put shortly, the question that falls to be decided is Is it within the companypetence of the companyrt to examine the grounds companymunicated to a person detained under the Act, with a view to see if they are sufficient in its opinion to enable him to make a representation to the detaining authority against the order, and if they are number, to direct his release ? It is number settled by the decision of the majority in Gopalans case 1  that article 21 is applicable to preven- tive detention except in so far as the provisions of article 22  4  to  7  either expressly or by necessary implication exclude its application, with the result that a person cannot be deprived of his personal liberty, even for preven- tive purposes, except according to procedure established by law.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order releasing the respondent set aside; habeas corpus petition dismissed; detention upheld

As regards the companytents of that companymunication therefore he test appears to be whether what is companyveyed in the second companymunication is a statement of facts or vents, which facts or events were already taken into companysideration in arriving at the companyclusion included in the ground already supplied.

In our opinion, this view is erroneous. We think that on the facts of the present case therefore the respondents petition should have been dismissed. We therefore allow the appeal. PATANJALI SASTRI. J.--While I concur in the order pro- posed by my Lord that this appeal should be allowed, I regret I find myself unable to agree with him on the true meaning and effect of article 22, clause  5 , which is reproduced in section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950,  hereinafter referred to as the Act . Put shortly, the question that falls to be decided is Is it within the companypetence of the companyrt to examine the grounds companymunicated to a person detained under the Act, with a view to see if they are sufficient in its opinion to enable him to make a representation to the detaining authority against the order, and if they are number, to direct his release ? It is number settled by the decision of the majority in Gopalans case 1  that article 21 is applicable to preven- tive detention except in so far as the provisions of article 22  4  to  7  either expressly or by necessary implication exclude its application, with the result that a person cannot be deprived of his personal liberty, even for preven- tive purposes, except according to procedure established by law.
